speaker: BILLY
line: It's just a damn passport photo. It's not the cover of 'Vogue'.

speaker: MARY
line: There's no reason I have to look like hell in it, is there? Now settle down.

speaker: BILLY
line: We're on a schedule here.

speaker: MARY
line: I know we're on a schedule here.

speaker: BILLY
line: Act natural.

speaker: MARY
line: I'll be back in ten.

speaker: BILLY
line: Make it five. I'll be around back.

speaker: MARY
line: Relax, Billy.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Lower it just a bit. Yep, that's it. Yeah... big smile... yeah... hold it. Big trip you got planned?

speaker: MARY
line: Oh, you know. Nothing special. Just good to have a passport.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Oh, it looks like it's clearing up. Might be a nice day after all. It's just going to take a few minutes. That comes to $6.95.

speaker: MARY
line: Great. I left my money in the car. I'll be back.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: I'll be here.

speaker: MARY
line: Ow! Hey, you jerk!

speaker: MARY
line: What? Billy? Billy, someone did something to me, Billy.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Shoot!

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: My God!

speaker: LONG LAKE ROAD, NORTHERN MICHIGAN, 5
line: 10 AM

speaker: MULDER
line: What are your thoughts on that, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Have the local police been contacted by this woman's abductor? No demand for ransom?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, unfortunately. It's going on three days.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Any additional leads?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no hair and fiber evidence either. The rain washed it all away. The autopsy did come back on the dead boyfriend, though. It's a puncture wound through the left eardrum and into the brain, possibly from a long needle or awl.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm still not sure how you and I figure into this investigation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't you see the photo?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I assume that was taken by whoever it was who abducted her.

speaker: MULDER
line: It was taken by a sixty-five year old druggist moments before she was abducted. That's a passport photo from a local drugstore. The druggist who took that photo is the last known person to have seen Mary LeFante. Only he claims that wasn't the photo he was taking. He says the photo he was taking was normal in every respect. He only came forward to the police when he heard the woman was missing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, whoever it was that took this photo was obviously privy to the woman's abduction.

speaker: MULDER
line: That is what you would think.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: The damndest thing. Here it is just like I left it. It was under lock and key.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that where you keep it?

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Yes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mind if I take a look?

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Yes, help yourself. At first I thought I did something wrong when I took the picture. You see, there's that piece of paper you have to pull off. You have to do that just right.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm sure you did it just fine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your film's out of date.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: Is that against the law?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I was just making an observation.

speaker: DRUGGIST
line: I don't get much call for passport photos, you know. The copy shop over at the mall does them cheaper. Excuse me. I sure hope you find that young woman, safe and sound.

speaker: MULDER
line: So which one of us gets to use the stun gun on Bruno Hauptmann back there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right, so he doesn't exactly stand out as a suspect. Mulder, take a look at this. See this smeariness here. I'm thinking that it's heat damage. With the heater sitting under the film right there, the emulsion probably melted.

speaker: MULDER
line: So you think that would make it look like she posed screaming for a passport photo?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Plus, the film is two years out of date.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The, the photographic chemistry could have changed. The, the dyes... fade, they... all right, so what's your theory?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure I have a theory.

speaker: TROTT
line: Excuse me. You the two FBI agents?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, agents Mulder and Scully.

speaker: TROTT
line: Sorry to have brought you all the way from Washington. Afraid we may have wasted your time.

speaker: TROTT
line: Inspector Puett. These are agents Scully and Mulder.

speaker: PUETT
line: Agents.

speaker: MULDER
line: Inspector.

speaker: PUETT
line: United States Postal Inspector. My office is investigating a mail theft - one which we've traced to your missing person, Ms. Mary Louise LeFante.

speaker: SCULLY
line: She was a postal employee?

speaker: PUETT
line: She works as a sorter at the Kurland Hills Branch. Not coincidentally, a number of unsigned credit cards in transit through that branch never made it to their respective owners.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mary LeFante was intercepting them.

speaker: PUETT
line: And her recently deceased boyfriend was signing them. We ran him, he was into forgery, check fraud, you name it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mary LeFante's passport photo. Do you know how soon she wanted to leave town? Did she know about your investigation?

speaker: PUETT
line: Probably, though we didn't focus on her specifically until this week after she came up missing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you think that she faked her own disappearance?

speaker: PUETT
line: Well, it looks that way to me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but why would she stab her boyfriend through the ear? The magic was gone? Did you find a camera anywhere here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: So you're thinking this woman planted that photo of herself in the drugstore?

speaker: MULDER
line: What would be the point of that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Here it is. Stand back, Scully, it's loaded.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: In the sixties, a bellhop named Ted Serios became kind of famous for taking what he called "thoughtographs". He claimed that by concentrating on an unexposed film negative, he could create a photographic representation of what he saw in his mind. He did landscapes, cathedrals, the Queen of England.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "Thoughtographs?"

speaker: MULDER
line: Also known as "skotographs." The literature on thought photography dates back almost to Louis Daguerre.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So that makes it legitimate?

speaker: MULDER
line: Look at that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh my God!

speaker: MULDER
line: I think he was here, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who was here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Mary LeFante's abductor. I think he stalked her. He could have come up right here. I think he came in here and he looked at her through the window, this close. Close enough to affect the film in that camera.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Psychic photography? Mulder, I think that it's obvious that somebody doctored these images and planted them to be found here. Maybe as some kind of a smokescreen.

speaker: MULDER
line: Meant to conceal what? This isn't about mail fraud, Scully, that's just incidental. What if... what if... someone had this ability? An image like this would be a peak into that person's mind.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Into their darkest fantasies.

speaker: MULDER
line: The fantasy of a killer.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: She's completely nonresponsive. We did a preliminary tox screen on her found traces of morphine and scopolamine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Twilight sleep.

speaker: MULDER
line: The dental anesthetic.

speaker: DOCTOR
line: It's basically a painkiller cocktail. It's also for women in labor.

speaker: MULDER
line: Would that account for her condition?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, it wouldn't.

speaker: MULDER
line: What would?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Give her a PET scan.

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: All set.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh my God.

speaker: MULDER
line: What is it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: She's been given what's called a transorbital lobotomy. It used to be known as an icepick lobotomy. It involves inserting a leucotome through the eye sockets.

speaker: MULDER
line: So we're looking for a doctor? Someone with training?

speaker: DOCTOR
line: Not judging by this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Whoever did this, Mulder, did it wrong.

speaker: MARY
line: un... un... unruhe... unruhe...

speaker: MULDER
line: Mary?

speaker: MARY
line: un... un...

speaker: MULDER
line: We better go in there and get her.

speaker: MARY
line: Unruhe... un... unruhe...

speaker: TROTT
line: We just got the call. There's been a second abduction.

speaker: MAN
line: Unruhe. Hab keine Angst. Ich verde dir helfen. Du wirst deine Unruhe bald vergessen... deine Unruhe vergessen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Charles Selchik, certified public accountant... dead from a stab wound through the ear... cleaning crew found the body.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about the missing woman?

speaker: MULDER
line: His secretary, Alice Brandt, age 32. Her family confirmed that she was working late last night.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's her connection to the first victim?

speaker: MULDER
line: Apparently none, but if the M.O. remains the same...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, the clock is running.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. I keep thinking about that word that Mary LeFante was repeating - "unruhe." I checked the Michigan phone directory. It appears under three different spellings but none within 80 miles of here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It might be significant as a word.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's what I've been thinking. Apparently in German, it means trouble or strife.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "Unrest."

speaker: MULDER
line: You took German in high school, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: College.

speaker: MULDER
line: Unrest, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm working on these crime scene photos from the first abduction. If we're lucky, we're dealing with someone who gets a vicarious thrill from returning to the scene of a crime.

speaker: MULDER
line: He wasn't there, Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you know?

speaker: MULDER
line: It would have affected the photos. Trott, what did you find?

speaker: TROTT
line: Nothing much. There's no cameras or film here whatsoever. It's all just accountants' offices so I don't know why there would be.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that what we're looking for here, Mulder? More evidence of psychic photography?

speaker: MULDER
line: That may be the only evidence we get.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I've got a bureau forensics team coming up from Detroit.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's here for them to find? This guy is obviously very good at what he does. He's left behind no witnesses, no latent prints. The only thing he's left are those photos, which leads me to believe he doesn't even know that he has that ability.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We haven't found any new psychic photos here either.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wait a second.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I want to show you something.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right here. This. And look. It's the same company. What if the kidnapper was working construction at both sites? From these two vantage points, he would have been able to pick out the two women.

speaker: MULDER
line: You may be right, Scully, you should check it out. Let me know what you find.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you going to be?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll be back in DC. I want special photo to run this. I still think the answer is in here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What if it's not, Mulder? This woman's time is running out.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's all the more reason to fully investigate the one and only hard piece of evidence we do have. I'll be in touch.

speaker: MAN
line: Das ist für dich. Es ist wie das, dass sie getragen hat.

speaker: ALICE
line: Oh, get away from me! Get away from me you bastard! Let me go! No! No!

speaker: MAN
line: Shh... shh... Bald sehr... sehr bald.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you get rid of the blurriness surrounding her, here?

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Yeah. I just need to mark a place where the blur comes to a point, and let the computer do its business.

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Bingo. Lord, look at that. This guy's an artist.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why do you say that?

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: However he did this, however he put this together, it's seamless.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about this face, here? Can you bring that up at all?

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Wait a sec... Let's try... I think I can sweeten it more.

speaker: MULDER
line: OK, do that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What have you got?

speaker: CORNING
line: We're running the construction company employees. Eighteen workers overlapped on both job sites. We're checking the records now, but so far nothing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about day laborers?

speaker: CORNING
line: Mr. Iskendarian, there, says that his company doesn't hire workers off the books...

speaker: ISKENDARIAN
line: I don't want any trouble with the IRS.

speaker: CORNING
line: ... but that his foremen might hire a little cash-only day labor without his knowledge. He's got seven job sites going now, as many foremen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Gather officers to canvas. Which foreman was working the Midlothian Corporate Park?

speaker: ISKENDARIAN
line: That job's finished.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Find out where he is today. I'll take that one.

speaker: ISKENDARIAN
line: Can I use your phone?

speaker: MULDER
line: OK, thank you. NCIC shows no match for that man. How about this shape up here? What is that? Can you take that and flip it so that that's on the bottom? Is that a shadow?

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Yeah, it is. Somebody's shadow.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the kidnapper's shadow. It's like he's looming over her, it's like he's standing over her, he means to pass judgement on her, like a god.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hello? Hello? Hello? Hello?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Hi, can I help you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, I hope so. Are you the foreman?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Yes, ma'am. Gerry Schnauz.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm Special Agent Dana Scully. I'd like to ask you some questions about the day laborers that you hire.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: What, is this some IRS thing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, sir, not at all.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Well, my crew is at lunch if you want to talk to anybody, but everybody I've got on today is on the books, as far as I know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me. Sorry.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Sure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, I may have something for you on the kidnapper. It's something about his legs.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah?

speaker: MULDER
line: They're unusually long, they're out of proportion. I'm thinking he's either very tall, or he's not but wants to be. Scully? Scully, are you there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Unruhe. Stand where you are!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't move!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Stop or I'll shoot!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hands behind your head! DO IT!

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Who?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Alice Brandt. The second woman that you abducted. That's her name, Gerry. Where is Alice Brandt?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: I don't... I have no earthly idea what you're talking about.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Tell us where she is, Gerry.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: I'm sorry. This is a case of mistaken identity or something. I honestly... honestly have no idea what you're talking about.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Explain this.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: We're running sheetrock today. I use that to start the holes in the sheetrock, to keyhole in all the fixtures.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, you used this to kill the two men.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: What two men?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You used this on Mary LeFante.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Who? What? Wait, a minute ago it was Alice Brandt. I don't believe this, I do not believe this is happening.

speaker: MULDER
line: You want to tell us about the first time you were arrested, Gerry? In 1980, you attacked your father with an axe handle. You beat him so severely that he spent the remainder of his life in a wheelchair.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: I was not jailed, I was institutionalized. I had a kind of chemical imbalance.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, Gerald Thomas Schnauz, diagnosed and treated for a paranoid schizophrenic disorder six years in Melvoin Psychiatric Hospital, released 1986. So what you been up to since 1986, Gerry?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Taking care of my father. Looking after him 24 hours a day. Making amends. He, uh, passed away January.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, how did you feel about that?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Sad.

speaker: MULDER
line: Says here that you have a sister. Where is your sister, Gerry?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: She passed.

speaker: MULDER
line: Actually, it says here she committed suicide in 1980. That was a bad year. What else happened in 1980, Gerry?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Well, John Lennon got shot. Where the hell are you going with this? What are you, Sigmund Freud? Why don't you cut the BS?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then why don't we get back to Alice Brandt. Where is she?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: You look troubled.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Gerry. This your father?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Where'd you get that?

speaker: MULDER
line: You left it for me. You left it like a fingerprint. Is this what you see when you close your eyes, Gerry?

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that what you see? Gerry... tell me where Alice Brandt is.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: She's safe from the howlers. She's all right now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Gerry... Tell me how I can find her.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, that word "unruhe", "unrest", is bothering me. Maybe he thought he was curing them somehow, saving him from damnation, from those things in the pictures, you know, he called them the howlers.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's over, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, then that photo wouldn't be his fantasy. It would be his nightmare.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What the hell does it matter?

speaker: MULDER
line: Because I want to know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't.

speaker: TROTT
line: OK, Gerry. All in here, your wallet, jewelry, everything.

speaker: TROTT
line: Eyes straight ahead. Step over to the table.

speaker: TROTT
line: What the hell?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: This wound's in the wrong place. He was shot in the throat. He wasn't trying to save this victim.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We just got a report of a strong-arm robbery. It's at the drugstore where the first victim disappeared.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you. It's Gerry.

speaker: MULDER
line: He took the passport camera and all the film in the store.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He also took morphine, scopolamine, hydrobromide and insulin syringes. He's making more twilight sleep.

speaker: MULDER
line: He wants to continue his work.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, that job site that I arrested him at, Mulder. What if he's... what if he's already picked out his next victim? There were... there were apartment buildings on all sides.

speaker: MULDER
line: You think you interrupted his stalking?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let's go.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hold on a second. You bring the car around. I just want to wait for this. I'll be right there.

speaker: CORNING
line: Corning.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Corning.

speaker: CORNING
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Send units to the 300 block of Belmont Avenue. Check all of the apartments in the vicinity of that job site. I think he's heading back there.

speaker: CORNING
line: Got it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thanks.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully! Scully!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: CORNING
line: Sir? Agent Scully's Explorer just turned up. It's abandoned at a Park & Ride about 20 miles up the US 81.

speaker: MULDER
line: Any sightings?

speaker: CORNING
line: Uh, a report of an Audi stolen from the same lot.

speaker: MULDER
line: He's switching cars. He's going to do that two or three times. He's got six fingers here...

speaker: CORNING
line: Sir?

speaker: MULDER
line: He's got six fingers. What about his apartment?

speaker: SECOND OFFICER
line: Got a unit at his boarding house, but he ain't coming back.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about friends, relatives, co-workers? Does he have a summer house? A winter house?

speaker: CORNING
line: He doesn't seem to have much of anything. We're running a couple of phone numbers we found in his wallet but so far...

speaker: MULDER
line: Let me see his wallet.

speaker: CORNING
line: It's his father's obituary.

speaker: MULDER
line: Recipient of the Bronze Star medal during the Korean War... Gerald Schnauz, Sr., DDS. He's a retired dentist.

speaker: MULDER
line: He was here.

speaker: CORNING
line: Why would he take the chair?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let me go.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Shhhh...

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Es ist alles in Ordnung.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's over, Gerry. Let me go right now.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Ich werde dir helfen. Du wirst deine Unruhe bald vergessen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Aufhören! Ich habe keine Unruhe. Ich habe keine Unruhe. Ich brauche nicht gerettet zu werden.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Yes you do. Everybody does, but especially you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why? Why me, Gerry? Do I remind you of your sister? Why did your sister kill herself, Gerry? What did your father do to her?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: He didn't do anything. It was the howlers.

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK, then let's talk about the howlers.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: They live inside your head. They make you do things and say things that you don't mean, and all your good thoughts can't wish them away. You need help. You've got them - right there. Don't you feel them?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't have them, Gerry.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: See? They made you say that, just now, because they know I'm going to kill them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What if you're wrong, Gerry?. What if there are no such things as howlers? What if you made them up inside your head to explain the things your sister said your father did?

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Great. Now they got you talking like Sigmund Freud. I am on to you! I know your tricks! Besides, I've seen them, in that picture that your partner showed me. Pictures don't lie. You saw them too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If there are such things as howlers, Gerry, they live only inside your head.

speaker: MULDER
line: Six fingers, right. Why are there six? What?

speaker: CORNING
line: We've got the State Police looking as far south as Grand Rapids. Still no sign of him.

speaker: CORNING
line: Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Damn it!

speaker: CORNING
line: What do we do?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's five headstones. And the father makes six. Come on!

speaker: CORNING
line: Let's go! Let's go!

speaker: MULDER
line: Fan out. Check the tree line.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: Wh... what does this mean?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It means you need help, Gerry.

speaker: SCHNAUZ
line: No, I think what it means is that I don't have much time left.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, Gerry, stop!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder! I'm in here!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder! Help! Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: MULDER
line: Are you hurt? Get an ambulance!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Addendum to case report. After his death, a diary was found among Gerald Schnauz's belongings, written in the second person and apparently intended as an open letter to his father. It includes the names of his victims, the women he desired to save. My name is contained in the last entry. I have no further explanation for the existence of the photographs, nor am I confident one is forthcoming. My captivity forced me to understand and even empathize with Gerry Schnauz. My survival depended on it. I see now the value of such insight. For truly to pursue monsters, we must understand them. We must venture into their minds. Only in doing so, do we risk letting them venture into ours?
